newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Russia, Chechnya sign interim cooperation accord.
newsitem.headline: Russia, Chechnya sign interim cooperation accord.

text.p: Russian Prime Minister Viktor Chernomyrdin and the head of the rebel Chechen government Aslan Maskhadov on Saturday signed a framework cooperation agreement, Itar-Tass news agency said.
The accord lays down the principles of relations between Russia and Chechnya for the period before January 27, when the breakaway region is due to hold elections, Tass said.

Earlier on Saturday, President Boris Yeltsin, in a big concession to the rebels, ordered all remaining Russian troops to leave Chechnya, where tens of thousands have been killed in Russia's 21-month bid to crush the separatists.
Tass said the two sides had agreed to restore trade in goods and services by December 1 and work out customs regulations. Air, rail and road traffic is also to be restored.

Another agreement describing "special economic relations" between Moscow and Chechnya was to be worked out after the election in the region. Moscow has been mulling a proposal to make Chechnya a free economic zone.

More importantly, the two sides vowed to sign a special deal on the transport and refining of oil on Chechen territory. The rebel government promised to guarantee safety of oil refineries and pipelines.
The document also said that payment of pensions, salaries and compensations to those who had suffered in the fighting was a priority for both sides.
Russia and Chechnya vowed "not to take any action threatening the security" of either side and to coordinate actions in the defence sphere, Tass said.
